w:r.w:t: TITLE: Special Nouns – Common and Proper

The teacher will teach basic common and proper nouns by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: common noun, proper noun, mouse, soda, chocolate, Mickey Mouse, Coca-Cola, Hershey’s, person, place, thing, ani
mal, uppercase, lowercase, months, days of the week, cities,
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for common and proper nouns
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: mouse, soda, chocolate, common noun, proper noun
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about common and proper nouns!”
Sing/chant the song with your teacher
Sing/chant the song to your child. Have the child join in the second time.
Review what at noun is, a person, place, or thing (or animal).
Draw examples of each category of nouns

Circle a letter at random. Ask if it is uppercase or lowercase. The child should answer while do the action for big or little.
A common noun starts with a lowercase letter

Visual cue: Explain that any ordinary thing around you is a common noun (pen, whiteboard, marker, paper, computer, etc.
rcle the girl in the picture. Ask the child if we know her name. The child should say, no. Explain that she is just a girl, we don’t know her actual name.

A proper noun starts with an uppercase letter
A proper noun starts with an uppercase letter
while making big, stretched-out hands. Have the child repeat.
Visual cue: Wear a nametag today. Show your name with an uppercase letter. Explain that yes, you are a girl, but your specific name is _________ with an uppercase letter.

hat this IS a common noun because it is lowercase. Also explain that it is just a mouse. We don’t know his name.

Underline the word soda and say
Circle the group of words: person, place, thing or animal. Ask the student if it is a person, place, thing or animal.
Circle the first letter of soda. Ask if the letter is uppercase or lowercase. Underline the word
in the definition. Explain that this IS a common noun because it is lowercase. Also explain that it is just a soda. There is no name on the can.
Categorize what kind of noun it is (person, place, thing or animal)
Circle the first letter of Coca Cola. Identify it as lowercase or uppercase
and say them. Have the child repeat.
Circle the group of words: person, place, thing or animal. Ask the student if it is a person, place, thing or animal.
Circle the first letter of Coca Cola. Ask if the letter is uppercase or lowercase. Underline the
in the definition. Explain that this IS a proper noun because it is uppercase. Also explain that it is a SPECIAL soda. Many people drink this kind of soda.

Underline the word chocolate and say
Circle the group of words: person, place, thing or animal. Ask the student if it is a person, place, thing or animal.
Circle the first letter of chocolate. Ask if the letter is uppercase or lowercase. Underline the word
in the definition. Explain that this IS a common noun because it is lowercase. Also explain that it is just a chocolate. We don’t know the name of the company that made this chocolate.
Categorize what kind of noun it is (person, place, thing or animal)
Circle the first letter of Coca Cola. Identify it as lowercase or uppercase
and say them. Have the child repeat.
Circle the group of words: person, place, thing or animal. Ask the student if it is a person, place, thing or animal.
Circle the first letter of Hershey’s. Ask if the letter is uppercase or lowercase.
in the definition. Explain that this IS a proper noun because it is uppercase. Also explain that it is a SPECIAL chocolate bar. Many people like this company, the Hershey company.

Review the days of the week and months of the year by reading/saying each one

Tell if these words are common or proper.
Circle the months of the year. Have the child say them with you. Do the same with the days of the week.

Find some proper nouns on this map and categorize them (as person, place, thing, or animal)

Ask the child if they know their city. If not, circle any city and ask if it starts with an uppercase letter. Ask if it is a common or proper noun. Then ask if it is a special person, place, thing or animal.

nderline the letter that shows it is a proper noun.
Write a proper noun for each picture
Model writing a proper noun for the first picture. Show that you are writing a proper noun with an uppercase letter.
